title: 103_hr2110
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tuberculosis Prevention and Control Amendments of 1993". Programs of Centers for Disease Control. The "Tuberculosis Prevention and Control Amendments of 1993" amend the Public Health Service Act to provide $300,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 and additional funds for fiscal years 1995 through 1998 for grants related to the prevention, control, and elimination of tuberculosis. Authorized grants of $85,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 and necessary sums for fiscal years 1995 through 1998 for tuberculosis prevention, control, and elimination. Grants are made by the Secretary of Health and Human Services through the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, focusing on areas with a high incidence of tuberculosis cases. Authorized grants of $80,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 and additional funding for fiscal years 1995 through 1998 for tuberculosis prevention, control, and elimination. Administered by the Secretary of Health and Human Services through the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The program of grants allows for bulk purchases of medications and supplies for tuberculosis. Grants can also be used for services related to incarceration. Research, demonstration projects, education, and training are also included in the program. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may make grants for training centers regarding health professionals, with authorized appropriations of $80,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 and additional funds for subsequent years. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may authorize grants for up to 5 training centers to educate health professionals on tuberculosis prevention, including identifying drug-resistant forms. The grants can be used for screenings, treatment, referrals, facilities, equipment, and ensuring quality laboratories. The Secretary may authorize grants for training centers to provide sophisticated tuberculosis training to health professionals. Grants are subject to application submission and approval by the Secretary, with a maximum amount of $5,000,000 per fiscal year. The Secretary may authorize grants for training centers to provide tuberculosis training, with a maximum amount of $5,000,000 per fiscal year. Payments to entities from the grant cannot exceed 3 years and require annual approval. Evaluations of centers and dissemination of information are also required. Authorization of appropriations is provided for these purposes. Authorization of appropriations for tuberculosis training centers is set at $25,000,000 for fiscal year 1994, with additional funding as needed for fiscal years 1995 through 1998. The Public Health Service Act authorizes funding for tuberculosis training centers, with additional funding available as needed for research and research training regarding tuberculosis through the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. The Public Health Service Act authorizes funding for tuberculosis training centers and research through the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, with $50,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 1994 for tuberculosis research. The Public Health Service Act authorized $50,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 and additional funding for fiscal years 1995 through 1998 for tuberculosis training centers and research. The authorization of appropriations does not affect the availability of other funding sources for the same purpose. Construction or modernization of health facilities is addressed in Section 4. Section 1610 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow the Secretary to make grants for projects related to tuberculosis prevention, control, and elimination. These projects include construction, modernization, and renovation of medical facilities for medically underserved populations, as well as facilities for long-term care and incarceration. Grants may cover up to 80% of the project costs. The Secretary can provide grants for projects related to tuberculosis prevention, control, and elimination, covering up to 80% of project costs. In urban or rural poverty areas, grants may cover up to 100% of costs. $100,000,000 is authorized for grants in 1993, $250,000,000 in 1994, and necessary sums for 1995-1998. Optional Medicaid coverage for TB-infected individuals is expanded to include those who have tested positively for tuberculosis and meet certain income criteria. Optional Medicaid coverage for TB-infected individuals is expanded to include those who have tested positively for tuberculosis and meet specific income and resource criteria. Covered services include prescribed drugs, physicians' services, laboratory and X-ray services, clinic services, Federally-qualified health center services, and case management services for the treatment of tuberculosis infection. Limitations on benefits are also specified for individuals eligible for medical assistance only because of TB-related services.
